EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The EPA/RMP regulation requires that an Executive Summary be provided as part of the registration submitted to the EPA. 
Note: This summary includes additional information not included in the RMP Submit to assist Cebro Frozen Foods management, process operators, technicians, contractors plus all involved and affected employees towards safe operation. In addition, some of the detail provided within this summary was excluded from the submitted RMP as current public access to this detail could expose the facility and personnel to terrorist or criminal activity.

Cebro Frozen Foods prepared a Chemical Risk Management Program and Process Safety Management Program (RMP/PSM) in general accordance with state and federal regulations. The state risk management regulations, also referred to as the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) program, are codified in California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 19, Section 2745, et. seq. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) also regulates facilities with certain toxic and flammable substances. The federal regulations are codified in the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), Title 40, Section 68. Finally, both the California Occupational Safety and Health Administration (CalOSHA) and the federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) regulate facilities with certain acutely hazardous materials under the PSM standards as defined in CCR, Title 8, Section 5189 and CFR Title 29, Part 1910, Section 119, respectively.

This program was updated to satisfy the required 5-year update per section 2745.10(a) (1) and to make corrections as necessary. All elements have been reviewed and updated.

The following areas are addressed in this summary:

1.	Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source
2.	The stationary source and regulated substances handled
3.	The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s), including administrative controls

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Cebro has written an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) that covers accidental ammonia releases. Cebro will rely on outside responders from the Newman Fire Department and the Stanislaus County HazMat Team for mitigation of releases. The ERP details the steps for required notification of outside agencies and the public and states that the Cebro Emergency Coordinator will be in charge until such time as an outside responding agency assumes that role. Cebro management will oversee evacuation and remain in control until Newman Fire Department arrives, then Incident Command will be assumed by the senior Newman Fire Department official at the scene. The Newman Fire Department Incident Commander will be responsible for issuing notices for public evacuation and/or sheltering in place, if necessary. Cebro management will be responsible for making initial contact with Newman Fire Department via 9-1-1; Stanislaus County Environmental Management Department; CalOES, federal NRC, and any other agencies that need to be contacted. Cebro will rely on community responders for medical assistance as necessary. Responsibility for cleanup after the release is spelled out in the ERP.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Employees, community safety, the environment and product care are primary concerns at this facility.  Several PHA studies were conducted at Cebro Frozen Foods and the study team made recommendations for additional safety.  The most recent PHA study occurred in June of 2022 as part of the 5-year revalidation.

Cebro will respond to all suggested mitigation measures promptly. Cebro has established completion schedules for proposed actions. Management responses and support will be consistent with Cebro's commitment to safe and environmentall

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES 

Cebro Frozen Foods is committed to complying with all the regulatory requirements of the EPA Risk Management Program.  Cebro Frozen Foods has developed their Risk Management Plan / Process Safety Management (RMP/PSM) making up the CalARP program to document policies and address the implementation of these regulations. The PSM sections pertain to the prevention of accidental releases and include the Process Hazard Analysis study and procedures for operating, training, maintenance, emergency response, and others. The RMP sections pertain to management systems and include the Hazard Assessment (Offsite Consequence Analysis) Report.

In the unlikely event that a chemical release does occur at the facility, Cebro personnel are trained in the appropriate mitigation measures, relying on emergency services provided by the Newman fire department and the Stanislaus County Hazardous Materials Response team. Cebro will continue to improve ammonia-handling safety through the implementation of the prevention program elements of the RMP/PSM program.

All releases and near misses are recorded using the incident investigation forms.  All releases are to be monitored and readings recorded.  All releases and near misses are to be reviewed to develop policies and/or procedures that may prevent future incidents.

STATIONARY SOURCE ACTIVITIES AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

Cebro is located at 2100 Orestimba Road in Newman, California. The facility is approximately 2 miles west of Highway 33, which runs north and south through Newman. The area is zoned for agricultural and industrial use. Cebro is a family-owned business that produces frozen vegetables. Cebro constructed the main processing facility in 1993 wit

h all new refrigeration system components. A new cold storage warehouse was constructed in 2008 with new and refurbished refrigeration system components.

Anhydrous ammonia, the only regulated substance, is used in the facility's two refrigeration systems: the process system (Process 1) and the warehouse system (Process 2). The process refrigeration system, which is a closed system, contains approximately 17,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia. The process system provides cooling to the cold storage rooms, a quick freezer, and a plate chiller. The cold rooms are used to store fresh and frozen vegetables. The quick freezer is used for initial vegetable freezing. The plate pre-chiller provides cold water for cleaning and cooling the fresh vegetables. A second refrigeration system, the warehouse system, was constructed in 2008 to provide cooling to a cold storage warehouse built next to the processing facility. The warehouse system which is a closed system, contains approximately 11,500 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.

The quantity of ammonia in the process and warehouse systems mean that the systems fall under the OSHA PSM regulations and as a result, falls under the Program Level 3 regulations of the RMP/CalARP regulations and submitted as such. 

The RMP regulations require facilities to identify and evaluate chemical release scenarios resulting from potential failures of the chemical handling systems covered by the RMP. Program 3 facilities (and Program 2 facilities) are required to evaluate a Worst-Case Release Scenario (release parameters are defined by the regulations) and an Alternative Release Scenario. The regulations define a Worst-Case Release Scenario as "...the greatest amount held in a single vessel...released as a gas over 10 minutes." An alternative release scenario is identified as a release that is more likely to occur at the facility.

This facility has prepared Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios. These are not summarized herein as recommended by

EPA but are presented in the RMP.

RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

Cebro Frozen Foods Prevention Program is described in the CalARP program.  The Prevention Program implemented by Cebro Frozen Foods is essential to help prevent or minimize the effects if a release occurs.

Key objectives of Cebro Frozen Foods Prevention Program are briefly described below:

1) Maintain current and complete refrigeration system technical information.  
The facility has retained manufacturer OEM manuals, equipment drawings, etc. for reference purposes and aid in maintenance activities. (Addressed under the Process Safety Information Element)

2) Provide a thorough team evaluation of the ammonia refrigeration systems.  
The types of natural and human caused external events considered in the process hazard analysis include: 

?	earthquake, tornado, extreme severe weather, flood (see above for parameters used in the seismic analysis)
?	inadequate physical security devices (locks, lighting, fences) may lead to outside threats which may lead to an anhydrous ammonia leak - the facility does have fencing around the facility, lighting, locked and secured                   
        doors / fences, and multiple cameras throughout the facility
?	lack of security awareness training for employees to help identify internal threats - employees are trained on an annual basis on the importance of reporting security incidents both potential and real
?	anhydrous ammonia theft from equipment that is outside and not monitored - facility has a fence around the facility, there are cameras throughout the facility to monitor activity, the compressor pad fence has a sign 
        indicating authorized personnel only
?	a suspicious package is delivered with the intent to cause an anhydrous ammonia release - package drop-off at the facility is in one area which is away from the anhydrous ammonia systems

3) Written procedures and policies are in place that establish how the refrigeration system is operated and main

tained.  
The facility has developed standard operating procedures for the safe and normal operation and shut down of the ammonia refrigeration system. The manufacturer's OEM manual may be used for reference.  The standard operating procedures are periodically reviewed to ensure they reflect the current operating practices.

Prevention is the primary reason regular and scheduled maintenance is performed on the ammonia refrigeration system.  The systems inspection, testing, and maintenance schedule shall follow industry RAGAGEP, manufacturer recommendations, and/or industry practice to help maintain the system.  The facility utilizes outside contractors to perform routine and emergency maintenance on the system.  (Addressed under Operating Procedures and Maintenance Elements.)

All safety recommendations developed by the team are reviewed and addressed by facility management.   A priority list is developed, and target dates are set for the recommendations to reduce or eliminate hazards.  (Addressed under Hazard Review and Maintenance Elements).

4) Written procedures and forms are in place detailing how and when the facility must investigate accidental/incidental releases.  
The facility investigates releases and near misses that could have resulted in a release of anhydrous ammonia.  Recommendations are addressed and corrected by facility management.  Reports are kept for at least five years. (Addressed under Incident Investigation Elements.) 

5) Certification of refrigeration operators to safely operate the refrigeration system.  Cebro Frozen Foods certifies operators following completion of operator training and confirmation of the operator's ability to apply what they have learned.  (Addressed under Training Element.)

6) Employee involvement in the Prevention Program.  
This is addressed on two levels.  First, refrigeration equipment operators participate in the planning and evaluation of the Prevention Programs (e.g., PHA study team, writing and/or reviewing o

perating procedures, Incident Investigation team, etc.).  In addition, some of these elements are reviewed and trained on annually or every three years or if a change is made at minimum as required by the code and industry standards. This involvement encourages ownership of the Prevention Program and positively affects the operators' day-to-day activities.  

Second, all Cebro Frozen Foods employees and contract employees at this facility receive ammonia awareness training.  Additionally, they have access to the complete CalARP, the IIPP and more for review, comment, and input.  These activities improve the overall safety of the employees.

6) Compliance Audits: 
Verification of Cebro Frozen Foods's compliance with the CalARP program.  The audit process is an important tool to confirm whether each of the elements in the Prevention Program has been implemented and properly documented by Cebro Frozen Foods personnel.  Cebro Frozen Foods has established a Management System procedure to address any shortcomings, which the audit may find.  A priority list is developed, and target dates are set for any changes or corrections.   (Addressed under Compliance Audit Element)   

Program Consolidation
The documentation requirements of these programs have been consolidated in the documenting and record filing process. The documents and records are kept as identified in each element of the program.  The following identifies the practices and procedures for:

        Process Safety Information
	Process Hazard Analysis
	Operating Procedures
	Training
	Mechanical Integrity
	Management of Change
	Pre-Startup Review
	Compliance Audits
	Incident Investigations
	Employee Participation
	Hot Works
	Contractors

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The CalARP regulations require a review of the 5-year accident history at the regulated facility. The history must include "all accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known

y responsible operations.

Cebro recognizes that the RMP/PSM is a continuous process for evaluating, monitoring, and improving anhydrous ammonia handling operations at its facility. As such, this document and related attachments and program elements will evolve as Cebro continues their ongoing focus and dedication of risk minimization and safety improvement for their employees and surrounding community. Cebro will submit revised information if a change occurs that is considered significant and requires resubmission under the regulations. However, minor improvements/modifications to the RMP/PSM, related attachments, and program elements will be incorporated consistent with Cebro's internal review practices, and Cebro will maintain the most current versions onsite. Thus, the most current version RMP/PSM and related documents and elements maintained onsite may vary slightly from the information in submittals made to EPA and other regulatory agencies.

Refer to the master tracking log which will include scheduled improvements to reduce accidental releases either in process or planned for at this time.
